channel.title: Better way of doing this
channel.description:
Would there be a better way to do this shorten it a bit it just seems a bit sloppy. It's an exam. :D [code=html5]

.


' name=''/>
' name=''/>
' name=''/>
' name=''/>
' name=''/>
[/code]

item.title: Better way of doing this
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“The Web Guy, post:34, topic:544222”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=663103.msg4431914#msg4431914 date=1403603234]
We need to stop talking Ruby is only for web development. My servers content is in Ruby.

Heck we can even use Java for websites and it’ll be much better then using php.
[/quote]

PHP is a language that was built for just websites.
Ruby is a language that was built in general, to make programming more fun.[/quote]PHP was a language hacked together to make a homepage. I don’t use that term ironically at all; the language was completely nigger-rigged when it was first being built.

[quote=“The Web Guy, post:15, topic:544222”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=663103.msg4431738#msg4431738 date=1403547272]

[quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=663103.msg4431704#msg4431704 date=1403539815]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=663103.msg4431693#msg4431693 date=1403536743]

(When echoing)

$name = 'Slim Shady';
echo 'My name is '.$name.', isn't that cool?';

The above example outputs:
My name is Slim Shady, isn’t that cool?
[/quote]Actually this would output a syntax error.

It was an example.
I wrote it in two seconds.
I forgot that I can’t use apostrophe’s unless I escape them with a backslash.
It didn’t occur to me that I was using an apostrophe as I was making this in the two seconds.
It doesn’t matter if it throws a syntax error, I’m pretty sure OP got the jist that you can echo HTML and break the echo statement to include PHP variables.
Your post wasn’t beneficial at all to OP.
Go back to doing Ruby.
[/quote]I’ve never used Ruby in my life.

Death Style:

A better way wouldn’t be using PHP.
[/quote]BUT PHP RUNS EVERYWHERE?!

Right. PHP is used by so many websites.[/quote]I was being ironic. It doesn’t matter how many websites use it. That doesn’t change the fact that it’s a bad language.

Reasons Ruby sucks.. 1. Everything is pretty much an object, it's no fun in programming. 2. It's so simple that it takes the fun out of programming. 3. The syntax is horrible, and hard for a lot of people to comprehend. 4. Programming languages that don't have a semi-colon at the end are fudgeing annoying. 5. You know how fudgeing dumb the Ruby creators are? To save typing, they took an e out of elseif. So just remember, if you're make an if statement, and you need to continue, it's not elseif, it's fudgeing elsif. 6. PHP is geared towards website, Ruby can be used for what the fahk ever. 7. PHP is easier to get going, upload files to a webserver and you're good.
You've got to be kidding...

Read full topic

item.title: Better way of doing this

item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:32, topic:544222”]We need to stop talking Ruby is only for web development. My servers content is in Ruby.

Heck we can even use Java for websites and it’ll be much better then using php.[/quote]

PHP is a language that was built for just websites.
Ruby is a language that was built in general, to make programming more fun.

Read full topic

item.title: Better way of doing this
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Look into Blade templating and Twig templating

I personally use Blade because it’s integrated within Laravel, but have used Twig in a past project and it’s just as good really.

You could also incorporate one or two loops to try and cut down code, though that may decrease readability.

Read full topic

item.title: Better way of doing this
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Ruby has more to it, and is better for larger website, I can agree with that. I’m not stating whether Ruby is better, or PHP is better. I will say:

  • PHP is easier to learn for new programmers.
  • Ruby is better for large-scale websites.

Those two statements I can agree with.

Read full topic

item.title: Better way of doing this
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Ashi:

But you’re so wrong! Facebook and YouTube don’t use php! Neither does eBay. In fact none of the big brands do.

Facebook: http://www.zdnet.com/blog/facebook/why-facebook-hasnt-ditched-php/9536
YouTube: With the purchase by Google, they drove away from PHP a little, but YouTube still does use PHP.
Ebay: Can’t find many sources.

Facebook is the big one.

Just watch this… 18k PHP developers, about 720 Ruby developers… Stahp Ruby people… Staahp.

[youtube]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VBm5m1-Eonw[/youtube]

Read full topic

item.title: Better way of doing this
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:16, topic:544222”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=663103.msg4431741#msg4431741 date=1403548748]
Right. PHP is used by so many websites.
[/quote]
Can you link me to a few sites that do?[/quote]

Welp, pretty much every RSPS server’s site, because they all have some forums engine that uses PHP.

This site, Moparscape.

Facebook.

Yahoo.

Wikipedia.

Wordpress.

And uh… Amazon, Ebay, YouTube, Flickr, Apple, Digg.

For server-sided programming, PHP is used by 82.1% of website. http://w3techs.com/technologies/details/pl-php/all/all

Reasons Ruby sucks…

  1. Everything is pretty much an object, it’s no fun in programming.
  2. It’s so simple that it takes the fun out of programming.
  3. The syntax is horrible, and hard for a lot of people to comprehend.
  4. Programming languages that don’t have a semi-colon at the end are fucking annoying.
  5. You know how fucking dumb the Ruby creators are? To save typing, they took an e out of elseif. So just remember, if you’re make an if statement, and you need to continue, it’s not elseif, it’s fucking elsif.
  6. PHP is geared towards website, Ruby can be used for what the fahk ever.
  7. PHP is easier to get going, upload files to a webserver and you’re good.

Read full topic

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=663103.msg4431693#msg4431693 date=1403536743]

(When echoing)

$name = 'Slim Shady';
echo 'My name is '.$name.', isn't that cool?';

The above example outputs:
My name is Slim Shady, isn’t that cool?
[/quote]Actually this would output a syntax error.

It was an example.
I wrote it in two seconds.
I forgot that I can’t use apostrophe’s unless I escape them with a backslash.
It didn’t occur to me that I was using an apostrophe as I was making this in the two seconds.
It doesn’t matter if it throws a syntax error, I’m pretty sure OP got the jist that you can echo HTML and break the echo statement to include PHP variables.
Your post wasn’t beneficial at all to OP.
Go back to doing Ruby.
[/quote]I’ve never used Ruby in my life.

[quote=Death Style]
A better way wouldn’t be using PHP.
